awd_titl_txt: Correlating Shear and Drying Physics to  Carbon Microstructure and Electrochemical Performance in Composite Electrodes
awd_abstract_narration:
Electrodes composed of particle-polymer composites are used in a variety of technological applications including electric vehicles, microelectronics, and environmental remediation.  The efficiency of ion and electrode transport across the electrode strongly affects the overall performance of the electrode.  The electrodes are fabricated by flowing a concentrated suspension of particles over a surface and allowing the suspension to dry.  The resulting particulate microstructure formed at the surface influences charge transport of the final electrode.  The goal of this project is to visualize the evolution of the microstructure before, during and after the flow, coating and drying processes of electrode manufacturing.  The final films will be characterized and tested to help understand the relationship between processing conditions and electrode performance.  The research team will provide opportunities for students at various academic levels to participate in the research, including high school students who will be recruited to the project through the STAR and STAR LITE programs at Drexel.

This hypothesis underlying this project is that nanometer-scale carbon particles dictate properties of the wet slurry and dry electrode microstructure, which strongly affect charge transport.  Techniques are proposed to visualize the location of the particles and their connectivity during the coating and drying processes. To accomplish this, carbon-coated metallic nanoparticles will be seeded into the electrode slurry so that three-dimensional tomographic images of the slurry and two-dimensional elemental maps of the coating can be obtained. Microstructure visualization will be combined with in-situ measurements of slurry impedance during flow and drying, which will enable dynamic characterization of particle connectivity throughout the manufacturing process. Results of this project will provide practitioners with a better understanding of how material compositions and processing conditions can be manipulated to form more efficient electrodes.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
Better lithium-ion batteries would improve energy security and carbon emissions. Lithium-ion batteries are made up of resistive microparticles, conductive nanoparticles, and polymer binder. The microscopic structure and connections between these particles and polymers within a battery electrode film affects how fast electrons and ions can move through the battery, which in turn affects how good the performance is and how long the battery lasts before it starts to break down.

 

This project works to understand how manufacturing affects the structure of the particle-polymer composite and how that structure affects performance. To do this, we first developed new methods that can measure the electronic connections between the particles. We combined two microscopic electrical probes with different spacing, and this allowed us to penetrate the measurements into different depths of the film. We used theoretical models to predict the resistances as the film dried, and the differences between the big and little probes during drying told us how particles and polymer move around within the film during drying and coating. These measurements are not possible using existing methods, but understanding them will help develop more efficient coating and drying processes.

We also studied new polymers that could replace the toxic materials that are used today. We found that eliminating oxygen during the coating and drying process could improve the mechanical properties of the new polymers, and that this led to improved performance. Eliminating oxygen is not often practical, but adjusting the polymer formulation to overcome oxygen inhibition can accomplish the same goal. Finally, we tested the hypothesis that we could replace toxic chemicals with greener solvents. We found that the green solvents cause conductive carbon to agglomerate, which is bad for performance and lifetime, but that additional mixing steps without solvent can overcome this limitation.


Last Modified: 11/20/2024
Modified by: Nicolas J Alvarez
